newsitem.title: ISRAEL: New Israel finance chief vows to meet deficit goal.
newsitem.headline: New Israel finance chief vows to meet deficit goal.

text.p: Israel's newly appointed Finance Minister Yaacov Neeman said on Wednesday he would stick to budget deficit targets and favoured lowering income tax rates.
"As the national treasurer, I will ensure adherence to the budget law to the letter," Neeman told Israel's Channel One television. "I did not join the government to break the law."

Neeman did not say where he might cut the budget to ensure deficit targets set by law -- 2.8 percent of gross domestic product this year, 2.4 percent in 1998 and 1.2 percent within five years -- are met.
"We will sit down with each minister and reach agreement (on spending cuts)," he said. Deliberations on the 1998 budget are due to begin in August.
Treasury officials have recommended a four billion shekel budget cut next year.

But Israeli newspapers reported on Wednesday that promises Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu gave coalition partners to defuse government crises will cost the Treasury up to three billion shekels ($841.7 million).
Neeman said he has always favoured reducing the tax burden on Israelis.
"I will work towards lowering the (income) tax rate," he said, without giving any figures. The top income tax bracket stands at 50 percent.
"There must be a more equitable distribution of the tax burden. Direct taxation must not rise in Israel. If we raise direct taxation we will collect less revenues," Neeman said.
Earlier in the day, parliament approved Neeman's appointment to the post. He replaces Dan Meridor, a long-time rival of Netanyahu who quit in a power struggle with the prime minister last month.
Neeman told a news conference he could not give full attention to his new post for another month because he is also heading a panel on the issue of conversion to Judaism.

"To my great misfortune I have another position in addition to my position at the ministry, a position perhaps even more difficult than finance minister," he said at a news conference marking his appointment in parliament earlier in the day.
"The one fortunate aspect of this is that we have set August 15 as the date to complete the work. I hope we keep to this timetable and that I can devote my full attention to the ministry," he said.
The committee is working to find a compromise to controversial legislation that would enshrine in law Orthodox rabbis' long-standing monopoly on religious conversions to Judaism.
The legislation won preliminary approval from parliament in April but has caused an uproar in the influential Jewish community in the United States and is being challenged by non-Orthodox Jews.
Neeman, a corporate attorney and former Treasury director-general, is active politically but unusually for an Israeli cabinet minister has not held elected office.
Meridor's term was characterised by political infighting with Netanyahu and tensions with the central bank over monetary and fiscal policy.
